choices.A: Set the administrative distance 100 under the RIP process on R2.
choices.B: Filter the prefix 10.1.1.0/24 when redistributed from OSPF to EIGRP.
choices.D: Redistribute the directly connected interfaces on R2.
choices.C: Filter the prefix 10.1.1.0/24 when redistributed from RIP to EIGRP.

discussion.content:
This Config works: Answer A
------------------------------------
R2#sh run | s rip
 redistribute rip metric 1 1 1 1 1
router rip
 version 2
 redistribute eigrp 100 metric 1
 network 10.0.0.0
 network 12.0.0.0
 distance 100
 no auto-summary
-----------------------------------
R3#sh run | s router
router eigrp 100
 network 34.34.34.0 0.0.0.255
 redistribute ospf 100 metric 1 1 1 1 1
router ospf 100
 redistribute eigrp 100 subnets
 network 10.3.3.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 23.23.23.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
---------------------------------------
Answer B is wrong: the Correct is to filter 10.1.1.10 when redistribute from EIGRP to OSPF: Configs are 
---------------------------------------
ip prefix-list DNA seq 5 deny 10.1.1.0/24
ip prefix-list DNA seq 10 permit 0.0.0.0/0 le 32
route-map DDD permit 10
 match ip address prefix-list DNA
!
router eigrp 100
 network 34.34.34.0 0.0.0.255
 redistribute ospf 100 metric 1 1 1 1 1
!
router ospf 100
 redistribute eigrp 100 subnets route-map DDD
 network 10.3.3.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 23.23.23.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
!

I lab all router can ping PC1 =)))), maybe question is not true
PC 2 will not be able to reach PC1 The correct answer is B
You still will have a routing loop

100% agree. Labbed it. Reducing AD to 100 will always provide an exit for packets to 10.1.1.0/24. When this route is in EIGRP it's external, so it will be treated with AD=170. Within OSPF AD=110. Reduce RIP down to 100 then on R2 10.1.1.0/24 will always point out towards RIP domain.
After making lab you'll see that problem happens on R2; it redistributes RIP into EIGRP, which then gets redistributed into OSPF at R3. So R2 learns from R3 an OSPF E2 route with an AD of 110. It inserts 10.1.1.0/24 >> R3 into the RIB because the OSPF AD is lower than the RIP learned AD. 
Thus lower RIP AD to 100 and it will be preferred over the OSPF route.
very good. i dont need to test this one to understand. answer is A

What's result your config? 
B correct: It seems there is a loop because of mutual redistributions among RIP, OSPF and EIGRP domains. So we should filter out the prefix 10.1.1.0/24 when redistributed from OSPF to EIGRP (the second redistribution point) to prevent routing loop.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
HETKAR and Alnet are correct, and I just want to add simple clarification 
D - does not make any sense 
C - if you filter prefix 10.1.1.0/24 from RIP to EIGRP, this network becomes unreachable on R3 and R4.
B - there is no redistribution from RIP to OSPF that won't work as OSPF does not learn the prefix from RIP.
A (Correct) When the traffic goes to the R2, the router will have a choice - sent to the R1 (RIP AD is 120) or to R3 (OSPF 110). OSPF is learning the route from R4 via redistribution.
Route with the lover AD will be injected into the routing table.
So if RIP's AD will not be changed to 100, R2 will forward the traffic to R3, so the packet will not reach R1.
I was confused a bit when I saw this scheme first time. R2 OSPF is redistributed into the RIP and RIP redistributed into EIGRP
I hope it helps

When OSPF->EIGRP redistribute, by default OSPF router R3 does not send external-RIP subnet 10.1.1.0/24 (OSPF LSA type2 E2). So no need to worry about OSPF->EIGRP redistribution.

So Option.B gone

Selected Answer: A
itÂ´s A

Correct Answer is A. Traffic flows for the prefix 10.1.1.10 from R1(RIP)--> R2 (RIP) --> R4 (EIGRP 170) -----> R3 (OSPF 110) --------> R2 (OSPF 110) In R2 OSPF AD(110) is preferred than RIP AD(120). Because of that R2 flushes the RIP prefix(10.1.1.10) out of its routing table. So R4 and R3 will flush that prefix consecutively.
Ans. A is correct

Selected Answer: A
Answer A

Selected Answer: A
The core issue here is that When the RIP route redistributed from eigrp into OSPF on R3, R2 that is running OSPF will install the route as have better AD, causing the loop. The solution here then is use a distribute list to do not intall the EIGRP route ont the ospf procees and avoid the loop.

Selected Answer: A
Redistribution of subnet 10.1.1.0/24 on from RIP to OSPF on R2 with create an OSPF route to 10.1.1.0/24 with AD of 110. This one is preffered over the RIP route to 10.1.1.0/24 with AD 120.
Redistribution of RIP route 10.1.1.0/24 to EIGRP on R2 creates an external EIGRP route with AD 170. This route will not be chosen anyway.
So if you set the AD of RIP to 100 on R2 that route is chosen to reach 10.1.1.0/24.

Selected Answer: B
Given answer is correct. I was testing on GNS3 and is the best solution

It may seem that B solves the problem, which makes it difficult to choose an answer.

But B removes only the EIGRP route that passed from R2 in a clockwise direction.
The main problem is that on R2 there is an external OSPF route(counterclock-wise) that pulls all attempts to get to the PC1.

If in answer B we swapped OSPF and EIGRP, then it would fit. .

if the red arrow in the picture is a symbol to a redistribution, what we should have in R2 are : OSPF is redistributed into RIP, RIP is redistributed into EIGRP and an arrow between OSPF and EIGRP that i can't see where it is pointing at.

comments.content: typo - first line should say R2 trusts RIP

discussion.content:
A - solves the problem because R2 trusts RI and sends the 10.1.1.0 traffic to the left.
B - doesn't help because the problem is caused by redistributing the route from EIGRP to OSPF, not the other way around.
C - suppresses the 10.1.1.0 route from EIGRP, thereby preventing PC4 from reaching the subnet.
D - just ridiculous nonsense obviously.
This is a route looping problem, being the route is looping via redistribution from OPSF to EIGRP. Why would adding distance metric to RIP solve this?

comments.content: Because when R2 is trying to get to 10.1.1.1, it will always go LEFT to the correct destination if it trusts the RIP routes over the OSPF routes. With RIP having AD of 100 it is trusted over OSPF which is 110.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is: A

Looks like no answer is correct. Just labbed it. It works when you set an AD of 171 for OSPF routes on R2. But once the RIP distance is set to 100 on R2 instead R1 loses connectivity to PC3 because there is no redistribution from OSPF into RIP and the best route to PC3 in R2s routing table is via OSPF. So all routes from R3 must traverse EIGRP (since this is redistributed into RIP afterwards) which means that these routes must be in R2s routing table available via EIGRP. Nonetheless A makes most sense.

r2#show running-config | s router
router eigrp 1
 default-metric 1000000 1 255 1 1500
 network 24.24.24.0 0.0.0.255
 redistribute rip route-map set-rip-tag
router ospf 1
 network 23.23.23.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 distance 171
router rip
 version 2
 redistribute eigrp 1 metric 1
 network 10.0.0.0
 network 12.0.0.0
 no auto-summary

Selected Answer: A
Definitely A.

A is the correct answer. OSPF has the AD of 110 and RIP has the AD of 120. R2 will select the OSPF learnt info and eject the RIP route. Once the RIP route has been ejected then EIGRP cannot redistribute the 10.1.1.0/24 into EIGRP since RIP no longer has it.
A i just tested

comments.content: Where is the loop? If it's between R3 R4 (bouncing back and forth), then you need to filter it to prevent, hands down, no question. But if the path keeps going around the triangle, then the answer is to give it a way to get out of the triangle. To get it to exit the triangle you can lower the RIP AD to 100 (100, 110, 170 > 100 wins) and the RIP route then gets installed in the RIB at R2 providing a way out of the triangle. But again, if your traffic bounces back and forth between R3 > R4, then making changes on R2 will do nothing for you. Also changing AD keeps multiple paths in everyones tables, filtering makes sure you only have one way to get there (no failover path).

I don't see changing RIP AD to 100 helps as R2 will still route traffic via R1 even when I set the AD to 100 or 180.
R2#sh ip route | in 10.1.1.0
R 10.1.1.0 [120/1] via 12.12.12.1, 00:00:38, GigabitEthernet0/0
R2#show ip eigrp topology 10.1.1.0/24
IP-EIGRP (AS 100): Topology entry for 10.1.1.0/24
 State is Passive, Query origin flag is 1, 1 Successor(s), FD is 2560256
 Routing Descriptor Blocks:
 12.12.12.1, from Redistributed, Send flag is 0x0
 Composite metric is (2560256/0), Route is External
 Vector metric:
 Minimum bandwidth is 1000 Kbit
 Total delay is 10 microseconds
 Reliability is 255/255
 Load is 1/255
 Minimum MTU is 1500
 Hop count is 0
 External data:
 Originating router is 24.24.24.2 (this system)
 AS number of route is 0
 External protocol is RIP, external metric is 1
 Administrator tag is 0 (0x00000000)

discussion.content: B is correct as 10.1.1.0/24 is redistributed into both OSPF and EIGRP at R2. This causes a routing loop as R3 is redistributing between OSPF and EIGRP. So to prevent the routing loop, you can filter the prefix 10.1.1.0/24 from OSPF to EIGRP. Changing the AD to 100 for RIP on R2 won't affect the route 10.1.1.0/24 learned on R3 and R4, because it's learned from OSPF/EIGRP as it's redistributed. Not learned directly from RIP. It will also not matter on R2 because the only route installed in the RIB will be from RIB, assuming that the routing loop is prevented with the aforementioned prefix-list.

B is correct as 10.1.1.0/24 is redistributed into both OSPF and EIGRP at R2. This causes a routing loop as R3 is redistributing between OSPF and EIGRP. So to prevent the routing loop, you can filter the prefix 10.1.1.0/24 from OSPF to EIGRP at R3.

Answer A: does solve PC1 connectivity to PC2 and PC4, but PC3 cannot communicate with PC1. R2 prefers the OSPF route to 10.3.3.0 and does not redistribute OSPF into RIP, so R1 never learns about 10.3.3.0/24 prefix - this is true for every possible answer given. I assumed OSPF contains 10.3.3.0/24 range as in the diagram and redistribution is on R2 between RIP/EIGRP and R3 between OSPF/EIGRP. Giving R1 a summary 10/8 or default to R2 fixes that.
B is correct
A. Set the administrative distance 100 under the RIP process on R2.
The given answer is correct

correct answer is B.
EIGRP AD is 90, R2 can not receive OSFP redistributed route to EIGRP, or it can form a loop.it must deny 10.1.1.0 form OSPF to EIGRP

comments.content: Only 1 route would have that AD. The AD will be 110 since the routes would be learned via redistribution and another routing protocol..

discussion.content: The given answer is correct

comments.content: In this scenario redistribution on R2 is among RIP and EIGRP (not including OSPF) so R3 is learning 10.1.1.10 as an external OSPF router from R4. Ans A is correct.

discussion.content:
B is the correct answer.
Only R2 and R3 are doing redistribution in this scenario. 10.1.1.10 is learned on R4 as external EIGRP router from R2. 
R3 is learning 10.1.1.10 as an external OSPF router from R2.
R3 should be configured to share its own connected routes in EIGRP and filter the 10.1.1.0 network which it learns from OSPF neighbor while redistributing into EIGRP to R4. Because, R4 is already having that network in the topology table (learned from R2)
B is correct
The problems starts when Redistribute from EIGRP->OSPF R4 to R3,R2 so for C answer it must filter the prefix from EIGRP->OSPF, otherwise the correct Answer is A

comments.content: I missed, the correct answer is A. I thought about the fact that redistribution on all routers in all protocols (in this case, there will be no problems at all). Probably there is no redistribution from the RIP to the OSPF, for the R2 -R4-R3 route, the route to R2 will be chosen through the OSPF (in this case, it will flop, since the RIP will not be able to redistribute if the route to the RIB is not chosen through it), respectively, it will be enough to choose AD 100 for this protocol. Answer A is correct.

discussion.content:
I think the correct answer is C. Because when redistributing from OSPF to EIGRP back to R2, it will come with AD 170 and will not affect the choice, since R2 will not enter this route from the OSPF into the routing table(rule RIB -> Database/Topology), but will only announce to its neighbor. However, in the opposite direction from the EIGRP to the OSPF to R2, the route will already come from AD 110 and get out the route through the OSPF.
Since there is no option to filter the prefix from EIGRP to OSPF. Only option C remains.

A is wrong, this will only work for the connection from PC2.
The other routers have no RIP routes, redistribution turns the RIP route into and EIGRP and into an OSPF route.
The redistribution replaces the original AD of 120. Into EIGRP this is not an issue because the 120 will be replaced by 170 because it becomes an External route.
But the issue starts when this route is redistributed from EIGRP into OSPF (AD=110), so B is the correct answer.
I tested that and A is the correct answer

but R3 has no RIP enabled, so the OSPF AD > EIGRP AD issue has not been solved there.
The only bad thing for doing the suggested answer is you lost the redundant route to the network

discussion.content: correct me if I am wrong, but RIP AD 120, OSPF AD 110, EIGRP AD 170 for external routes. OSPF always wins in this scenario, so the best answer would be A, change RIP AD to 100 and it will always win.
b is the correct answer.

choices.C: ip tcp payload-mtu 1360 crypto ipsec fragmentation after-encryption

questions.question_text: A newly installed spoke router is configured for DMVPN with the ip mtu 1400 command. Which configuration allows the spoke to use fragmentation with the maximum negotiated TCP MTU over GRE?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is corerct

Selected Answer: B
"When IPsec is being used, it is customary to set the MTU size on the tunnel interfaces to 1,400 bytes and to set the TCP-MSS-adjust to 1,360 bytes. "
https://www.networkworld.com/article/2224654/mtu-size-issues.html
For me "# crypto ipsec fragmentation before-encryption" would make more sense, but that option is not give, so I vote for "B".
" If the routers are performing fragmentation on behalf of the source node, it may be desirable to have the fragmentation performed prior to encryption, so the destination tunnel router doesn't have to reassemble the fragments and then perform the decryption."
https://manualzz.com/doc/33447188/configuring-ipsec-vpn-fragmentation-and-mtu

Selected Answer: B
Correct!

R5(config-if)#crypto ipsec fragmentation ?
 after-encryption Perform fragmentation of large packets after IPSec
 encapsulation
 before-encryption Perform fragmentation of large packets before IPSec
 encapsulation.

Option correct is D: Because, D is necesary while execute maintanance windows. The option A is wrong, because that command is for uRPF: muRPF is a security feature that helps limit or even eliminate spoofed IP packets on a network.
This is accomplished by examining the source IP address of an ingress packet and determining whether it is valid. If it is valid, the packet will be forwarded. If it is not valid, the packet
Chapter 22: Infrastructure Security 853
will be discarded. Note that CEF (Cisco Express Forwarding) must be enabled on the IOS
device for uRPF to work

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. During ISP router maintenance, the network produced many alerts because of the flapping interface. Which configuration on R1 resolves the issue?

comments.content: I still don't understand, can someone explain why it is A.

Just figured it out.
With DHCPv6, currently there is no equivalent of the "default-router" option as in DHCPv4. The following draft describes a way to handle this with DHCPv6, but it's currently not implemented:

http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-mif-dhcpv6-route-option-04

Also see section 5.5.2 (Absence of Router Advertisements) in RFC 4862. Basically, the assumption is that the dhcp client still needs to learn the gateway through RA, so you still need to enable RA on the router.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/ipv6/dhcpv6-problem/td-p/1971648

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
In IPv6, hosts locate a router through Router Advertisement (RA) messages sent from routers instead of by DHCP; IPv6-enabled routers that support dynamic address assignment are expected to announce themselves on the network to all clients. As such, DHCPv6 does not include any gateway information

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
OPTION A CORERCT:

questions.question_text:
A customer requested a GRE tunnel through the provider network between two customer sites using loopback to hide internal networks. Which configuration on
R2 establishes the tunnel with R1?
